utterance.speaker: Jane Doe
utterance.content: Hi. Sounds like a good party.

utterance.speaker: Bouncer
utterance.content: 20 bucks.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Okay. No problem, I, ah, I just got it in here somewhere. Oh god, I’m - I’m sorry, I guess I must have forgotten to go to the machine.

utterance.speaker: Bouncer
utterance.content: Yeah, and ah, brush your teeth. Lady, you don’t have two cents.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: I can - I can get it from - from my friend who’s inside, he can give it to me and then I can bring it back out here to you.

utterance.speaker: Bouncer
utterance.content: You don’t know anybody here.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Yes I do! James, he’s blonde and he’s really friendly and he’s a big talker. I need to see him.

utterance.speaker: Bouncer
utterance.content: Go on in.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: James? James? James?

utterance.speaker: Tall Girl
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Do you know where James is?

utterance.speaker: Tall Girl
utterance.content: Oh yeah, he’s, he’s around here somewhere.

utterance.speaker: Tall Girl
utterance.content: Let’s go find him.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Where is he?

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: I really need to find him

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Short Girl
utterance.content: Bitch!

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: NO! She’s trying to help me… get off her! Get off me!

utterance.speaker: Policeman 1
utterance.content: Settle down!

utterance.speaker: Policeman 2
utterance.content: Move!

utterance.speaker: Policeman 1
utterance.content: Geez, I didn’t touch her.

utterance.speaker: Policeman 2
utterance.content: Great. Now we gotta go to the hospital.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Homeless. Admitted 24 hours ago with a suspected drug overdose. Her tox screen’s clean, but she’s still delusional.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Homeless, usually means crazy; no money. Cuddy’s not going to like this –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We’re a teaching hospital. No ID. Doesn’t even seem to know her name. I got called in because of some lesions on her arm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Homeless always means no roof, at least, there’s too much sun

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The lesions were non-cancerous, but I noticed a twitch. Her wrist.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Mmph

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You feel that?

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Sure. I’m human.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Make a fist around my fingers, tight as you can. Squeeze.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: I am.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right. All right. Raise your arms above your head for me.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Oh…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She’s seizing. Get me some Ativan.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She doesn’t want to be discharged. She’s manipulating me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s real. Check her finger sticks.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Blood sugar’s 38.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I need D15. IV push stat.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fake low blood sugar. Now that’s acting.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The blood sugar was real. But she’s probably diabetic. OD’d on her own insulin. I need 2032. Do you have her effects out here? Look, a seizure buys her a place to sleep while the nice doctors run their tests, maybe a few free meals. $20 says there’s insulin in here. Oh… put this back, please.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What about the twitch?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her arm moved.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why fake a twitch? In case the seizure was too subtle? A twitch could indicate a tumor, which could indicate–

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A need to see a neurologist, which is why you called me. Keep an eye on her until 2:00 PM, watch her blood sugar, give her a nice hot lunch, and discharge her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’s wrong

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman is wrong? The neurologist is wrong, about a neurological problem?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He took one look at her and figured it was a scam.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, you figure he’s not being objective

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, the woman had a twitch. She had a seizure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Both of which Foreman saw?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He just wanted her out the door!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whoah, whoah, whoah, back up there, big fella. Foreman’s the guy you want to take a swing at.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I - just - want her to get some medical attention.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not even close to being true. Something else. Something personal. Give me the file. Looks like this will be fun.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The twitch could be a mini-seizure, unrelated to the diabetes.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Brain tumor?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Glad you could join us, Eric. What’s the differential for a twitch in the wrist?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The patient’s a thirty-ish Jane Doe. I just thought I’d discharge her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, she’s my patient. No harm in a second opinion.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A blow to the head? A subdural hematoma?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Read the file, no evidence of cranial trauma.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A twitch could indicate a brain tumor

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or about a dozen other things. Come on, there’s two things homeless people are good at – getting sick, and running scams. If you’re so worried about it being a brain tumor, get her an MRI, when she’s clear on that, then you can bounce her out of here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, you’ve got her all figured out.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ve known a lot more homeless people than you have.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes, you’ve got that going for you. How could I have doubted your medical opinion?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The big question, you’re missing it, all of you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh, geez.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who is she?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay. Why are we on this case – just because Wilson asked?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do I need a better reason?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Most people wouldn’t, you do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The only thing we know for sure about Jane Doe is that her name isn’t Jane Doe. Which means no medical history. Allergies, medication, previous diagnoses, treatment – we have no baseline, no context for medical treatment.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wow. Looks just like insulin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Vomit. Still moist. What do you think - a couple of days old?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Uhhh… trying to make me hurl?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. And here’s the big finish…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Salty. Chemical imbalance.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Low magnesium could cause a twitch.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or high calcium. Or it’s a coincidence. The point is, we don’t know anything.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So do the MRI. Find out –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The MRI can wait. Hang a banana bag, give her 24 hours to correct the electrolyte imbalance, we’ll take it from there.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Great. Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay. Even if she’s not faking, what’s so fascinating about this case?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: At the moment, how much you don’t want me to take it. That’s pretty fascinating.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Nice likeness of Dr. Foreman. In fact, he’s never looked better.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: He doesn’t like me. I can tell.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That’s okay. He doesn’t like me either. Who’s James?

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Ow! Oh!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pain in your head?

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: Get away from me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All right, let’s get it out. One milligram of Ativan, push.

utterance.speaker: Jane
utterance.content: NO! NO! NO! NO!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She bit me!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Good news is, she’s negative for HIV and hep-C.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah? Well, I’m getting a tetanus shot, she’s getting an MRI.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There’s a two day wait for non-emergency MRIs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s getting an MRI. And then she’s out of here.

utterance.speaker: Angela
utterance.content: Now Dr. Terharg specifically said I’d have the MRI at 10:00, it’s almost 11:00, and I haven’t even had the pretest yet.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Sorry, we’re a little backed up.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: Uh!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Excuse me, you’re Dr. Terharg’s 10:00?

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: I’m Angela Whitney. I’m meeting my decorator at 11:30, she’s coming all the way from New York. Dr. Terharg promised I’d be home in time.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’s just about prepped for her MRI? Mrs. Whitney?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You tried to steal someone else’s test?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dr. Terharg is a plastic surgeon. The woman was getting a six-month checkup on a chin implant.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I can’t believe you authorized this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? Sounds exactly like something I’d do.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She can’t have an MRI. The CT scan shows she has a surgical pin in her arm, the MRI magnet would have ripped it out of her body. You like the Alien movies? You had no medical history, what were you thinking?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’ll surgically remove the pin, then do the MRI, does that sound good?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She has an electrolyte imbalance.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Foreman, a neurologist, believes this woman has a brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Actually, I –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, don’t ever apologize for a medical opinion. If he’s right, we don’t do this test, the patient dies. Now I realize that you have a specialty of your own, but does yours have anything to do with the brain? His does.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine. But nothing more until you find out who she is.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How are we supposed to –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey! He knows more homeless people than any of us. Go check out the ‘hood, dawg.

utterance.speaker: Homeless Man
utterance.content: I don’t know. I’ve seen a lot of faces around here but I don’t think I know her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: Homeless Man
utterance.content: Hey, I ah, like that jacket. Yeah, it’s all coming to me now. I know where she keeps her stuff.

utterance.speaker: Homeless Man
utterance.content: Just bats. I thought the lining would be thicker.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No tumor, nothing. Her brain is clear.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Which means, that girl had surgery just so you wouldn’t get reamed out by Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Not necessarily, there could still be something neurological going on.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sure, she’s not conning us, the MRI is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not wearing a coat in this weather. That is so wrong.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She drew these. They might give us a clue.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She sign them? Her name would be a start.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All the mythology, the locations, they’re all dependant on life experience.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Philadelphia. Look at that skyline! It’s very evocative. The Chrysler Building.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s a cloud.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And the Chrysler Building’s in New York.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mmm… I’m getting Philly. And that cactus, well, that’s a smashed car – car accident.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A cactus in Philadelphia?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Water – well, water’s October, right?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Obviously.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: On the page number 22, so that’s October 2nd, 2002. Ergo, the patient was in a car accident two years ago last October.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: My goodness! Was she okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Broke her arm, I think. They fixed it – with this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Surgical pin. Better than a wallet. Serial numbers in case of recall, tied to a patient’s name.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s why you insisted on the MRI. So you could remove the surgical pin from her arm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You didn’t think I was going to do it to save your sorry ass, did you? You might want to take a look at that. Her name is Victoria Matson, at least that’s the one she used then. Any hospital with the record of treating her should be sending that information.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh, crap!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her blood work came back an hour ago, magnesium was normal.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Did you change her banana bag?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Stopped the magnesium, started iron dextran for severe anemia. She’s allergic to iron dextran!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Grab some Epi off the code cart. Respiratory arrest, call the code!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You have an allergic reaction, can you speak?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s not getting any air. Got the Epi.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Stats down in the 80s and dropping.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We have about another minute.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, we got her sedated and stabilized.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And we still think there’s nothing wrong with her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, nothing’s changed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We almost killed her – that’s different. And we know who she is.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So far we’ve heard from three hospitals with records of Victoria Matson. Seven visits, going back two years.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Any home addresses?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The pin in her arm went in during an ER visit. She wasn’t conscious, so they didn’t get an address. The other visits she gave fake addresses.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Any treatment for neurological problems, anything that might explain the twitch?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Last winter, Jefferson Hospital in Philly, got treated for frostbite.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Baby, it’s cold outside.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And depression. They put her on Prozac.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, I’d be bummed out too. Zero degrees, living in a box.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Put her back on it. She cheers up; she might stop biting people

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There’s a billing record from Hartman Hospital last year. Two appointments, ultrasounds, doesn’t say what for.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pregnant?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Only if she was expecting an elephant. The appointments were ten months apart. Kept the first, blew off the second.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Abdominal pain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The chart doesn’t say –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wait a minute. She goes in the first time, they look, they can’t find anything. Ten months later, why should she subject herself to that again?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why make a second appointment?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She didn’t. The nurse made the appointment. They were looking – they were looking for ovarian cancer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You got all of that from one cancelled appointment?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: With Jerry Lousing, yeah. He’s an oncologist.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hang on, her current blood work doesn’t show cancer. CA125 is normal.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And the cancer wouldn’t account for the alleged twitch, or any other of her alleged symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, it would. Neoplastic Syndrome associated with the cancer could cause her to twitch like a bunny on crystal meth. Ultrasound her ovaries.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Did you find a brain tumor on her MRI?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Foreman was wrong. I’m starting to wonder about that guy’s medical chops.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Right. Shelley Diamond?

utterance.speaker: Shelley
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. House is ready to see you now.

utterance.speaker: Shelley
utterance.content: The little ones are licking each other again, and Harry’s got a seeping wart on his extra toe. What room should we go to?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know, I think I might be coming down with something. Hate to give it to you guys. Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh yeah. Just walk out, like I’m not going to do anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bye-bye.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Working hard?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This stuff’s pretty good. Calendrica, works for the counseled genius. Bad guy’s Mr. Fury, fairly generic, no special skills, but apparently very well organized. Think you work hard, try ruling the universe.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You trying to teach me something here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’ve got the flowing dress, the ring. Think the patient was married? Maybe it was a bad break up, maybe he dumped her cause she was on drugs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You care about her personal history?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Question is, why don’t you? I hate to cite a cliché, but – Dad on the streets?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dad’s with Mom.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They’re both living on the streets?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No! On a pension.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So who pissed you off?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pfft. Right now, you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your turn, you gonna tell me why this case?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She’s my new girlfriend, I’m having a tattoo designed, I was hoping you could find out her name.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So she’s just another sick person the kindly Dr. Wilson has made sure doesn’t get lost in the big ugly system.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes, I forgot, I need a reason to give a crap.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re giving two craps.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The metric system always confuses me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Time for Girl Scout cookies already?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Get me some Thin Mints.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Since you’re too sick to work in the clinic –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: – I thought you –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: - I thought you could do some teaching. Patient histories.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My specialty.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: When you teach, you learn so much, don’t you think?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s all about the giving back. Good old Cuddy. Always thinking. She assign you a patient to interview?

utterance.speaker: Students
utterance.content: Mmmhmm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then why are you still here?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why are we on this case?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because Wilson asked House to do him a favor.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I think House just wants to prove she’s sick so Foreman will be wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh, you boys.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hey, I’m just doing my job. Whoah. Foreman’s going to be so embarrassed when he finds out she’s got cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh. I thought you were too sick to be down here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Had to get away from those students so I faked a page. Foreman’s parents, happily married, 40 years.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Mazel Tov.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Keinahora. So, why does he hate homeless people? If it’s an uncle or a grandparent you’d think he’d use it in his college application essay. Family struggles beats a 4.0 GPA any day.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think he had a 4.0

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maybe he’s just a snob.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You really don’t need to know everything about everybody.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t need to watch the OC, but it makes me happy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, delirious. What’s the other file?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wilson, James. Boy wonder oncologist. You know him?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You know, in some cultures, it’s considered almost rude for one friend to spy on another. Of course, in Swedish, the word friend can also be translated as ‘limping twerp’.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Did your pager really just go off, or are you ditching the conversation?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why can’t both be true? Come on.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Solid non-cystic mass on the left ovary. Five by three centimeters, central necrosis. The only question is whether she dies in two months or three.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh, God.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You were right. There’s nothing we can do for her here. Might as well put her back on the street.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless it’s not cancer.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh, you’re joking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, hard not to – nothing funnier than cancer. But what if it’s a tuberculoma. She’s living out on the streets, breathing all kinds of crap 24/7. The odds are she’s got TB, why can’t she have a nice benign growth to go with it?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: A solid mass on her ovary. Ovarian cancer’s way more likely.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re right. It’s not even close. Start her on INH, Rifampicin and Streptomycin.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But that’s the treatment for a tuberculoma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And what is the treatment for advanced ovarian cancer?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pine box.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: What are you giving me?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A second dose of some antibiotics. If you’ve got a tuberculoma, it should help.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: I don’t have a tuberculoma, do I?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Probably not.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Listen – I’m sorry I didn’t believe you.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: I’m sorry I lied to you. I took too much insulin on purpose; I really wanted a place to sleep.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Were you ever – married, Victoria? But in the comic –

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: No, it’s a comic, comics are just made up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So who’s James? Is he real, or did you make him up?

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: He’s real.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Can I help you find him?

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: The – the light’s bright – it’s getting brighter – – ow, ow!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Take it easy, take it easy, everything’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: Mr. Fury wants to hurt me, please, help me!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wait, wait, wait, hold on…

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: – turn it off – please turn off the –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All right, hold on Victoria. Take it easy, everything’s fine. Take it easy, everything’s fine, Victoria.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: I’m burning! It’s burning!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hold on. Take a sip, take a sip.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: It’s poison, you gave me poison!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hold on. Take it easy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, turn off that damn light!

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: Help me, help me, please!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Take it easy, take it easy. The bad guys can’t get you here, I’ve got you covered.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: Mr. Fury’s not the bad guy, I’m the bad guy, it’s me, I’m the bad guy…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not a tuberculoma. Can’t be.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn’t know the biopsy was back.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her temperature’s 105. Treatment’s not working, it’s cancer. She’s dying.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Good news! It’s a tuberculoma.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How do you figure that? Her temp’s through the roof.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s the lab results from the biopsy, it’s definitely a tuberculoma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So – we’re right about the diagnosis, and the treatment for that diagnosis is killing her. Perfect.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The lab checked the biopsy again, twice.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, a tuberculoma doesn’t give you a temperature of 105.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Then it’s a tuberculoma and something else.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The something else is gonna to melt her brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Poach. Better metaphor.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A fever that high has to be bacterial.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe the bowel got nicked in the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I did the biopsy – no nick! She could have picked up an infection on the streets.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, she didn’t have a fever when I admitted her!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The Prozac we’ve given her could have triggered Serotonin Syndrome, which would explain the fever.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No! Jefferson put her on Prozac, and it wasn’t a problem.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She probably never took it! Most likely they saw her one time and dumped her out of the ER with a script.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, just like you were going to do!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay you two, grab some scalpels and settle this like doctors. Send blood and urine cultures and get a chest x-ray. And fine, take her off Prozac and put her on Bromocryptin for the Serotonin syndrome.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Might want to get her in an ice bath as well, assuming we want her to live long enough to see those test results.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: I said I was sorry.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your fever’s 105. If we don’t bring it down fast –

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: Foreman, why are you doing this to me?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’re saving your life.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, come on – you can do this.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: Ple-ee-ease!

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: 17 year old female presents with abrasions and apparent trauma injury to her wrist – Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Continue.

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: You’re reading a comic book.

utterance.speaker: Student 2
utterance.content: I thought you were supposed to be listening to our patient histories

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. I’m supposed to be teaching you. If I can do that without listening, more power to me.

utterance.speaker: Student 2
utterance.content: 17 year old female –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This guy’s supposed to have universal power over all of gravity; how come his hair won’t stay down? That’s just stupid.

utterance.speaker: Student 2
utterance.content: – she fell off her horse while riding in the county fair.

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: No, she didn’t, she fell off the steps of her beach house, you must have gone to the wrong room.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hard to believe that one patient could slip past Cuddy and get herself admitted with a sprained wrist. Two seems almost impossible - what room?

utterance.speaker: Students
utterance.content: Room 2106

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Patients lie. But usually only one lie at a time; how much does she weigh?

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: It’s her wrist not her –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Poundage, ladies, and by the by, what color is her nose?

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: She’s thin –

utterance.speaker: Student 2
utterance.content: Flesh toned.

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: What does this have to do with her wrist?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Almost nothing. She’s either under 90 pounds, or she has a red nose. I gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: What’s wrong with her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That would be telling. Oh, I am just too nice. It starts with ‘C’.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Urine cultures are negative.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So’s the chest x-ray.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I assume there’s a positive coming.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Lumbar punctures revealed elevated proteins and white counts.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: CSF cultures?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Still growing. Nothing on Gram Stain. It looks like meningitis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We know it’s definitely an infection. And we know where it is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, meningitis is nice and simple. Get her in isolation and start her on Ceftriaxone. Either she gets better or she dies. Let me know which one happens!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh my God. She was sedated.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It must have worn off.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I – I did it myself, a half hour ago.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll check the nurse’s station.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Calendrica.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s gonna die out there.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You don’t walk out of a room with ten milligrams of Haldol in your system, you don’t walk at all.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It was ten milligrams, I gave it to her –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It doesn’t matter! Bacterial meningitis, highly contagious, if she is out of the hospital, we are so liable.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Not to worry. She’ll be dead before she can kill anybody.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Security tape confirms it, she stole some clothes and she’s gone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wrong coat. The cape’s in the closet, I had it cleaned.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Funny.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You gonna save her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: In her comics, Mr. Fury lives in Sloan Harbor. The night she came in, she was at a rave at 1408 Sloan Street.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ve been reading. My, how you’ve changed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You are a doctor; do what doctors do. Pick up the phone, dial 911 and a cop on the other end does what cops do and finds the missing person! I assume the rest of you have doctor things to do – I know you do.

utterance.speaker: Student 2
utterance.content: Cacchi-Ricci disease.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you even know what that is, or are you just guessing everything that starts with ‘C’?

utterance.speaker: Student 2
utterance.content: The kidney problems could result in weight loss.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cacchi – C-A-C- she’s going alphabetically.

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: Doctor, why are you wearing that bird pin?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It sets off my eyes. Hi, Jodi, I’m Dr. House. What brings you to the hospital?

utterance.speaker: Jodi
utterance.content: My wrist.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How did that happen?

utterance.speaker: Jodi
utterance.content: I was riding the Ferris wheel and this huge seagull flew right at me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How horrifying.

utterance.speaker: Jodi
utterance.content: I swung my arm at the bird, but I hit the Ferris wheel.

utterance.speaker: Student 2
utterance.content: She’s making it all up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, her wrist really does hurt.

utterance.speaker: Jodi
utterance.content: I’m not lying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course you are. You have no idea what happened. You have no memory. Korsakoff’s syndrome. Her brain is damaged by excessive drinking or insufficient diet; pretty obviously the latter. She has no new memories, no new ideas, can’t even process that idea. So her brain fills the gaps as best it can using visual clues. The horse on your shirt led her to the riding accident and the surf scene on your clipboard led her to the beach.

utterance.speaker: Student 2
utterance.content: Korsakoff doesn’t start with a ‘C’.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn’t say ‘C’. Or did I? Lesson to be learned – treat everybody as if they have Korsakoff’s, we all lie anyway. Give her Thiamine right away, she’ll bounce back pretty quickly. And then get her to eat some cake and ice cream.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: Student 1
utterance.content: Did you need to be so cruel? I think she’s crying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hi! Jodi, I’m Dr. House. What happened to your wrist?

utterance.speaker: Jodi
utterance.content: There was this weird old guy, he had a cane –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See? It’s like it never happened. Perfect forgiveness.

utterance.speaker: EMT
utterance.content: Pulse is rapid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You got a temp?

utterance.speaker: EMT
utterance.content: Don’t know. She’s warm, but –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s something to look into; she has meningitis.

utterance.speaker: EMT
utterance.content: Sorry, I was more worried about her heart blowing up. Pulse is 150.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Rhythm regular?

utterance.speaker: EMT
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ready – one, two, three.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where’d you find her?

utterance.speaker: Policeman
utterance.content: Battlefield State Park

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: {something} Narrow Complex? She wasn’t at Sloan?

utterance.speaker: Policeman
utterance.content: She was just passed out on the grass.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: Foreman… I need Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All right. Super ventricular tachycardias. Get me Adenosine, one milligram, push. Thank you. Hang in there.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her arrythmia stabilized.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It doesn’t make sense. What would push her heart rate over 150? Dehydration? Fever?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Unlikely. By themselves, neither one would do it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We must be wrong about the meningitis. Maybe it’s structural heart disease.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Her heart rate dropped when you administered the Adenosine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Two seconds.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s still meningitis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If it is, with the delay in treatment, she’s got almost no chance.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start the treatment.

utterance.speaker: Policeman
utterance.content: Read the report. I found her lying on the grass.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You should read my reports. I make up stuff all the time. What really happened?

utterance.speaker: Policeman
utterance.content: Oh, since it’s you… I found her lying on the grass.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow. That is a great looking gun.

utterance.speaker: Policeman
utterance.content: It’s not a gun. It’s a taser.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s so cool looking. What does it do? Fire about 60,000 volts? At least, that’s what it would take to jack someone’s heart up to 150s.

utterance.speaker: Policeman
utterance.content: Okay. Okay. Let’s just say I tell you what happened. This stays between you and me, right? I found her. Lying. On the. Grass.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. Don’t tell me. Tell my friend, Ben Franklin. I watch a lot of cop shows.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The good news is, the heart rate thing’s not connected to her condition.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well then, she’s dying. The meningitis treatment isn’t helping her, she’s getting worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, that brings us to the bad news. The cop tasered her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The first time he hit her in the thigh, and she just kept going, like it was nothing. Right about here. She didn’t feel the taser.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Localized numbness?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, in that one spot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The diabetes?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t think so.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No alcohol. Not entrapment syndrome. Can’t be a vitamin deficiency. We can’t chase down every sensory neuropathy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is that where she bit you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What the hell?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can’t get angry if you don’t feel anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: First there’s localized numbness, then sensitivity to light, disorientation, paranoia, ineffectiveness of sedatives, and then hydrophobia. Fear of water.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Rabies.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There’ve only been, what, 20 cases in the last ten years?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. That’s because non-homeless people, when they get bitten, they get shots.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There were bats.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She’s dying.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There’s no treatment.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How much time does she have?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A day, maybe two. And if you don’t get your shot in, say, the next three hours, I’m going to have to make another affirmative action hire.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Come on.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Do it. Mmmph.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You want me to talk to her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And say what? There’s some experimental treatment, but it’s not gonna work. Don’t worry, we can make you comfortable? Doesn’t matter how. She’s gonna die.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. That’s what you say to her. Keep that there and rest for a minute.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Mmm…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Whoah, whoah, whoah!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tell House I need to go out for about an hour.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She may not have that long.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t want her to die alone.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re going to find James.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m gonna try.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, I must say – he’s done a lot with the place.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hello?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey – this is it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Man, no one’s been in here for a long time.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This has got to be James. Maybe there’s another address.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s not James. Paul. Paul Furia.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Mr. Fury.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Her husband.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Then who’s James?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Her kid.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: Oh, I just want to eat you up. You’re so delicious.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: Aw, look at me, you’re just like your papa. Look at you. Just like your dad.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Foreman. Foreman. They’re dead. That car crash two years ago – she broke her arm… and they were killed.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She was driving.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: James.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No. It’s Paul.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: You’ve come to take me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No. I’ve come to forgive you. It wasn’t your fault.

utterance.speaker: Victoria
utterance.content: I’m so sorry… I’m so sorry… I’m so sorry.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I know. It’s okay Victoria. It’s okay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh. You followed me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. You were wearing rain boots today, but you were parked in the underground garage, so the only reason you’d need boots was if you were hitting the streets… I followed you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Didn’t we have a conversation about friendship?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. I had some follow up questions. I’ve met your parents, and your brother –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I have two brothers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why wouldn’t you tell me –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It was irrelevant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Because he’s not in my life any more.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, that’s relevant.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: This was the last place I saw him, nine years ago. I don’t even know if he’s alive.
